African governments have had 30 to 40 years of independence to increase transparency. This is, alas, more than many of their citizens' life expectancy. Does the noble Baroness agree that channelling aid through NGOs and civic organisations would produce both greater accountability and cost effectiveness of funds?

I cannot discuss corruption without reference to the NePAD peer review mechanism. We welcome the participation in NePAD and, indeed, the African Union's mounting and ambitious operations in the region. But the review system remains a disappointment. Described as,
"a voluntary process based on self assessment",

it does not rate governments according to a score card for governance, transparency and suitability for donor support. Thus I suggest that those taking part will not be subject to much peer pressure at all. Will the Minister inform us how they will achieve a collective commitment to govern well to make the system work?

It is also true that no economy can fulfil its potential without independent institutions and freedom under the rule of law. Aid must be used carefully to assist the development of property rights and civic institutions as the foundations of wealth creation. I fully support the very positive speech of my noble friend Lady Chalker. I also support the speech of my noble friend Lord Eccles. It is imperative that we address the issues surrounding trade. However, international companies that invest in Africa, especially our own, must follow the principles of corporate social responsibility.

I apologise for not being able to cover debt and many other issues including military expenditure and land reform. I would simply like to urge the Government to turn all their weighty words into action, and hope that we will see significant progress in the wake of the summit.

We need to be reassured that African governments genuinely share our determination to create a better future for their people; otherwise, it will be yet another opportunity missed. This is the best opportunity that we will have for a long time.

My Lords, I add my very warm thanks to those already offered to the noble Baroness, Lady Park, for giving us this opportunity to discuss the Government's response to the report of the Commission for Africa.

I say to the noble Baroness, Lady Northover, that in between the publication of the report and this evening's debate we have had the small item of an election. That is why we have not had a debate beforehand. I thank all noble Lords who have participated in this debate for their very constructive contributions. The wealth of knowledge and experience shared in one short debate is truly quite extraordinary.

The commission was set up in response to the challenges Africa faces. On current trends Africa is the only continent that will fail to meet the millennium development goals. But it was also set up in recognition of the progress that Africa is making, and the confidence it now has that it is in a position to succeed. I am glad that that point was endorsed by many noble Lords this evening. For example, governance is improving across Africa, and the creation of the African peer review mechanism will embed that further.

The report is a comprehensive call to action based on analysis of what works and, more importantly, of what does not. It says clearly that Africa's future is in African hands and that African leadership is crucial. It also recognises Africa's diversity. But clearly the international community also needs to get behind Africa's efforts with a comprehensive package of support. In today's interdependent world it is in our common interest to do so.

The launch of the report in March was just the beginning of a very long process. The Prime Minister said at the launch that he was committed to bringing UK policy into line with the commission's recommendations. There is much in the report that chimes with what we are already doing. For example, in terms of improving aid quality and making better progress on harmonisation, the commission's recommendations reflect what the UK has been trying to achieve.

I shall attempt to answer the many and varied questions that were put. The noble Baroness, Lady Park, asked why there was a Chinese commissioner. The commissioners act in a personal capacity as active people in their fields. The fact that there was a Chinese commissioner was perchance in many ways.

The noble Baroness, Lady Park, the noble Lord, Lord Blaker, and many others raised the much more difficult problem of Zimbabwe. The vivid descriptions of the abhorrent situation are deeply shocking, but I must emphasise that the Government are taking action. We are working with our international partners to emphasise the abhorrence of the regime, for example, by extending the asset freeze and the travel ban. We are engaging African partners as regards the importance of an honest assessment.

Good governance goes hand in hand with economic and social progress but neither Africa nor NePAD should be held responsible for the actions of a single country. The peer review mechanism is an important step forward, but it is a long-term agenda. As many noble Lords said, the needs of Zimbabwe are urgent. However, Zimbabwe reinforces the need for change and the need for NePAD.

I shall certainly draw to the attention of my right honourable friend the Prime Minister the proposal that Zimbabwe should be considered by the G8 in the ways outlined by the noble Baroness. I thank the noble Baroness for her interesting suggestion regarding President Mbeki, the Prime Minister, Bob Geldof and a possible visit to Zimbabwe. I am absolutely confident that the Prime Minister is very acutely aware of the situation in Zimbabwe and the despicable actions of Mugabe. I fear that any visit as outlined by the noble Baroness would play into the manipulative hands of Mugabe.

My noble friend Lady Warwick referred to improvement in skills and the benefits of trade. Of course, those are both very important in providing a long-term solution to the problems of Africa. Investment in people is certainly a prerequisite for a flourishing Africa. My noble friend mentioned the neglect to date of tertiary and secondary education as outlined in the report. We certainly support the work to revitalise Africa's higher education as part of a balanced approach to education that covers primary, secondary and tertiary education. That must be led by Africans in response to their needs and their priorities. I am pleased to say that DfID is investing up to £3 million a year through higher education partnerships which promote development collaboration between universities. The current programme will be phased out in March next year and replaced by a new scheme.

Of course, we must also be aware of our responsibilities to African countries in terms of building the skills of their people and ensuring that there are careers and career opportunities in African countries so that Africans want to stay in their countries. That has been one of the problems to date. If there is no career structure, people do not want to stay in their countries.

I am pleased to say that by providing significant support to strengthen health systems in Africa, including country-led strategies, we are addressing shortages of human resources for health. One example is work in Malawi where the UK is supporting the government there with £100 million to strengthen health systems, including implementing an emergency human resource programme. That programme aims precisely to double the number of doctors, nurses and other key workers in Malawi.

Naturally I agree with the emphasis placed by my noble friend on the need to widen trade. We must improve trade and conditions for trade both with Africa and within Africa. For Africa, it is clear that although market access is important, it is the supplier response on which we must build if international trade is to contribute to poverty reduction.

In answer to the right reverend Prelate the Bishop of Coventry, I wholeheartedly endorse the importance of faith-based organisations in and working with Africa and pay tribute to their excellent work. I thank the right reverend Prelate for focusing on the need to engage with African leaders as real partners in meeting the challenges in their countries. Africa's future must lie in their hands of Africa's people and governments. Our role is to provide resources to support their work.

In response to the questions raised by the right reverend Prelate, the report is addressed not only to governments, the UK Government included, but to the international community, including the private sector and NGOs, including faith-based groups, and we hope that they will respond favourably to its recommendations. Faith-based organisations as providers of services are extremely important: for example, providing a high proportion of educators in Africa. Where governments are weak and unable to provide services, we rely heavily on faith-based groups. Naturally, they have a right to work where they can fulfil a role. A number of donors provide funding specifically for faith-based groups.

As the right reverend Prelate noted, follow-up is crucial to the implementation of the report. So there is a strong focus in the report on implementation and monitoring. The Government will ensure that it does not just sit on the shelf but is followed up with tangible progress.

In response to my noble friend Lady Whitaker, the UK has one of the strictest arms export control regimes in the world and we fully support the goal of an international arms trade treaty to regulate all conventional arms as the best way to stop the flow of illegal arms to Africa and other regions caught up in the cycle of violence and destruction. We are currently discussing such a proposal with other governments.

In response to the noble Baroness, Lady Cox, she is absolutely right. Too many people in positions of power who do not want to know have not known what is happening. That was clearly the problem in the past. I hope that this report will make the real needs known. In focusing the attention of the international community on Africa, it will ensure that more people's eyes are truly wide open to the problems on that continent.

In respect of Sudan, DfID has been a major donor helping to reach humanitarian aims. It was the second biggest bilateral donor to the Darfur crisis, contributing £62.5 million from April 2003 to December 2004. It has allocated £75 million for humanitarian needs across Sudan this year.

In respect of fundamental freedoms, especially for women, the report states that the upholding of human rights, gender equality and good governance are at its centre. We of course welcome the adoption of Security Council Resolution 1591 on imposing targeted sanctions against those in Darfur responsible for the ongoing conflict.

I thank the noble Baroness, Lady Chalker, for her warm welcome. She is absolutely correct about the necessary order for action and the need to build institutions and ensure that aid is spent, and properly spent. I am delighted to say that the Government are supporting the investment climate facility, as so eloquently explained by the noble Baroness. The story of sound African management in a coffee company is extremely welcome.

I wholeheartedly agree with the noble Lord, Lord St John, that the report has been a catalyst and has put flesh on the bones of NePAD. Trade, aid and development must go hand in hand. They are three prongs that must go together. I am glad that the noble Lord highlighted the fact that not all of Africa is corrupt and there are some outstanding successes.

I thank the noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, for his focus on economic development, which is, of course, the road to sustainable poverty reduction. Private sector development needs enterprises, but enterprises flourish with confidence only if there is good governance. That is why there is such emphasis on good governance in the report.

In response to the noble Lord, Lord Alton, of course we must consign poverty and corruption to the history books. On conflict, peace and security is an essential precondition for poverty reduction. As for the prognosis for the people in the camps in Darfur, donors are providing relief for humanitarian needs and we are pushing all parties to abide by their international agreements.

The noble Baroness Lady Northover, asked many questions that I will respond to in writing. I assure her that the Government accept the report's recommendations and will act on them. We will sign up to the UN convention by the end of this year.

In response to the noble Baroness, Lady Rawlings, governance is the key; ratification is coming; yes, civic society and NGOs play a very important role, especially where Government cannot act. I will respond to her in writing about trade and various other matters.

I say briefly at the end that there is no question but that the Commission for Africa is an ambitious report and our agenda for Gleneagles is ambitious, but we are deeply committed to it and we will ensure that the report does not stay on the shelf but will work.
House adjourned at four minutes before eight o'clock.
